unnormalised: Mumbai: Accurate inventory forecasting is becoming increasingly vital for Indian manufacturers looking to optimize operations and minimize costs, particularly in the post-Diwali season. Dr. Anjali Sharma, Professor of Supply Chain Management at IIM Bangalore, emphasizes that "Effective forecasting reduces warehousing costs and avoids stockouts, ensuring timely delivery to customers like Mr. Patel in Surat."

unnormalised: Recent workshops across Tamil Nadu have highlighted the importance of leveraging data analytics and machine learning for prediction. Techniques like time series analysis and regression models help businesses like Gupta Enterprises estimate future demand for products, ranging from auto parts to handcrafted textiles.

unnormalised: Poor forecasting leads to tied-up capital (Rs. 5 lakhs in excess inventory is not uncommon) and requires larger storage spaces, like an additional 1000 sq ft godown. Investing in robust forecasting systems allows companies to streamline their supply chains, improve customer satisfaction, and gain a competitive edge in the global market. Early adoption of these strategies, especially before the busy festival season, could prove to be a game changer for many MSMEs across India.
